bioghist.p: Founded in 1809, the Walnut Street Theatre is the nation's oldest theater. It is the official state theater of Pennsylvania, and is a national historic landmark, a designation it received in 1964. It opened as The New Circus, showing equestrian acts. In 1811, its name was changed to the Olympic. In 1920, it became the Walnut Street Theatre. The same year, the interior of the theater was rebuilt based on a design by William H. Lee. In the 1920s, the manager of the theater was C.C. Wanamaker.

scopecontent.p: The Walnut Street Theatre collection consists primarily of financial records for the early part of the twentieth century. Materials include receipts for utilities, supplies, newspaper advertisements, and printing; treasurer's statements; weekly box office statements; and a small number of salary lists. The collection also includes a series of letters in response to a 1923 radio program, "Thumbs Down," in which the ending was left for audience members to solve.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
